author: english.ahram.org.eg
title: Egypt to prevent sale of stolen antiquities in London - Ancient Egypt - Heritage
text:
Related Parts of King Nakhtanebu I's shrine uncovered in Cairo Egypt recovers Stolen relief of King Seti I from London NMEC director receives France Knight of the Order of Arts and Literature INTERVIEW: Egypt's antiquities minister speaks on the search for Nefertiti in Tutankhamunâ€™s tomb Tutankhamun's treasures may have originally belonged to his stepmother INTERVIEW: Nicholas Reeves '60% sure' ahead of Nefertiti announcement Egyptian minister believes hidden chamber may not contain Queen Nefertiti Egypt's ministry of antiquities has taken all legal measures to stop the sale of a collection of original Islamic objects that are due to be put on sale in Sotheby's auction house in London on Wednesday, Minister of Antiquities Mamdouh Eldamaty announced Monday.
The minister said that the collection includes Islamic artefacts and manuscripts that go back to the era of Sultan Qunsuwa Al-Ghouri. Among these artefacts is an endowment that was registered in a book written by art professor Mohamed Amen entitled Cairo Documents Catalog until the end of the Mameluk Sultans.
The ministry reported the incident to the ministry of foreign affairs who, in turn, took all procedures to stop the sale of these objects as they are stolen and were illegally smuggled out of the country in the aftermath of 2011 January Revolution.
Two pages from 'Cairo Documents Catalog' book written by art professor Mohamed Amen
